Definition

Petrology is the branch of geology that deals with the study of rocks, including their composition, texture, and structure.

It focuses on the classification and analysis of the three major rock types: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. Petrology is essential in understanding the Earth's crust and the processes that form and transform rocks over time

Petrogenesis

The study of the origin of rocks, known as petrogenesis, involves investigating how different rocks are formed. This includes understanding the source materials (magma, sediments, or pre-existing rocks), the conditions under which they form (pressure, temperature, and chemical environment), and the geological processes that lead to their transformation over time.
